title: Best meal in ages
text: Was hungry for Mediterranean but tired of the places I've been. Decided to give this place a try. So happy I did! The chicken shwarma platter is so well spiced. Can't wait to try some other dishes there.

title: Enjoyed this place
text:
Cool, modern looking pasta place in Amsterdam. Not that one
s always looking for Italian in the Netherlands, but this place does a nice job.

title: When you can't walk anymore, eat here
text: Cute little place, staff was nice (I think one of the young waiters actually made a date with some other English-speaking tourists when we were first sitting down, good for him!) very much enjoyed my pasta alla amatriciana. Good bruschetta, house red wine was fine. My daughter ordered a different pasta which was also good.

title: Comfy place for your Athens visit
text: We had a reservation and arrived at about 8 PM, 2/2/20. My daughter beat on the door for a few minutes and one of the managers/owners appeared to let us in, they manage this somewhat remotely, kind of alarming at first, but a very nice gentleman appeared and got us situated, utterly charming guy. .The room was lovely, immaculate and comfortable, had everything we needed. My team was playing in the (American football) Superbowl at 2:30 AM that night, and I couldn't get the TV to work, and it never did - Wifi was fine. Otherwise, the hotel was perfect. There was a woman making breakfast out on the patio, the breakfast was very good, made to order. The hotel is very well located to anything you need in Athens (Syntagma square for transport) and all the important sights. I guess they're connected with the ice cream/sweet shop on the corner of the building, and they graciously gave us a discount. Highly recommend this hotel. I don't know when I'll be back in Greece again, I'm already aching to get back, but I'd stay here next time.

title: If you're in Prague, you'll go here anyway!
text: One of the highlights of Prague. If you're visiting Prague, you'll of course visit this. St. Vitus will take your breath away. it's glorious, on par with any cathedral in Europe. They don't actually let you see much of the castle, but what you can see is amazing. The last place we went was the hall of armor, the highlight of the whole place for me, and Golden lane. On my way out I hit the dungeon, which is real as far as I know, and ticked all my boxes as a fan of Medieval history, horror movies and Game of Thrones. I don't need to tell you this, you're already going there. Enjoy!

title: Very near the Pantheon, go
text: I'd been to Rome 10 years ago, and missed a lot of stuff due to travelling with kids. My travel partner, my youngest, is older now and a road warrior like me, so we finally went. It's beautiful, and the tromp l'olieil ceiling is worth seeing. My pictures are trash, but it's amazing and you should see it with you own eyes.

title: Not just the Mouth of Truth
text: Before our trip, my daughter mentioned she wanted to see this. It's just north of the Circus Maximus if you're visiting the Colosseum and Forum (and you should.) There was a huge line (even during very low tourist season) to get your picture with the Mouth of Truth. which is outside. Inside, the church is beautiful, they've got a shrine to the (alleged) skull St. Valentine. Wait in line if you want to, but go inside the church.
place: Basilica di Santa Maria in Cosmedin

title: You should visit
text: First visited 10 years ago, on my first trip to Rome. The crypts are of course the big draw. At the time, you just tossed a donation in a basket and visited about five very creepy arched rooms adorned with the artistically arranged bones of many many former monks (and children, not sure where they came from,) along with mummified Capuchin monks still in their brown robes. The last crypt has a sign that says ""What you are now, we once were; what we are now, you shall be" in several languages. They were hard core. Beware, you're going to remember seeing this. Since the first visit, they've added a stiffer admission price and a whole museum about the religious order. The church itself is beautiful, don't skip it. I remember standing there on my first day ever in Europe, jetlagged as all hell, thinking, "this is what a 500 year old church smells like?" Shakespeare could have gone there. You should too.
place: Santa Maria della Concezione dei Cappuccini

title: Just go!
text: I'd been looking at pictures of this and wanting to visit for 10 years. I missed it on my first visit and regretted it ever since. It's gorgeous, and obviously historically important. There are a lot of beautiful churches in Rome, but you shouldn't skip this one.

title: Time travel to ancient Rome
text: We were in Rome 10 years ago and I don't think they even had tours back then, so I wanted to finally see this. Buy your tickets online in advance, they only tour on weekends in small groups. We wore hardhats and walked through what they've excavated of Nero's palace from the first century. We had an English-speaking guide, and they do a fantastic (multimedia) job of explaining what you're looking at. At one point, you put on some VR goggles in a room and they bring the room to life, as it was, overlooking the valley with Nero's artificial lake (before they built the Colosseum there later.) It was incredible, like time travel. Cannot recommend this more highly. Also, the Google maps directions to the entrance are wrong. Ignore them, you'll get lost.

title: Stop by when visiting Sta Maria Tastevere
text: My daughter and I had already had a long day in Rome and stopped by here for lunch. We shared some bruschetta (fabulous) and I had some wide noodles with pesto, and they were glorious. Probably the best pesto I've ever had. It was a very relaxing break (and glass of wine) - do as the Romans do.

title: Wanted to go here my whole life
text: One of the greatest places I've been on earth! What can you say that will do this justice? Certainly a very important site in the the development of Western civilization. May be influential on the development of all civilization, due to their good ideas! I was most concerned about taking good photos here, but the historical significance of the place wan't lost on me.

title: Beautiful Monastery Church
text: We were at this church/monastery during early February 2020, so we were virtually alone. It's very pretty.

title: If you visit Athens, visit Aegina
text: We spent about four days in Athens, and set one aside to take a ferry over to Aegina, the nearest island. It was gorgeous and one of the highlights of our trip. Visit the Temple of Aphaia, the Nektarios monastery, eat at the seaside, see the seaside churches.

title: Amazing Temple!
text: We took a ferry over to Aegina from Athens in early February 2020, before the CV hit. This island is nothing compared to Santorini or Mykanos, but completely delightful. There are some very beautiful sights here, and the views of the Med will take your breath away.We were not there at typical tourist season and had this temple entirely to ourselves, it's gorgeous. I'd recommend visiting if you have a few days in Athens.

title: Very odd Bone Church
text: OK. This is an inexpensive and relatively easy one hour train ride from Prague. When I'm in Europe, and I like to see odd things I can't see in the U.S. The church is about a 15 minute walk from the train station. It's of course unlike anything you've ever seen, dark, dank, weird. Takes about 15 minutes. Harder to get to and see than the Catacombs of Paris or the Capuchin crypt at Sta Maria della Concezisone dei Cappuccini in Rome. Not entirely sure I'd recommend the effort. We didn't spend long here and raced back to the train station to catch an earlier train back to Prague so as not to waste time.
place: The Cemetery Church of All Saints with the Ossuary

title: See it with your own eyes
text: Pompeii is amazing, perhaps not quite what you might expect, but you have to go to understand. If you've seen a lot of pictures of treasures from Pompeii, some of them aren't even here, they're in a museum in Naples, be aware. That being said, there's a lot here to see. TBH, there's a lot of ruined houses with nothing worth seeing, punctuated by houses with breathtaking preserved mosaics, paintings, statues, etc. I'm not saying don't visit, I'm saying you have to do a lot of work to see what you're looking for. Lots of walking, over old Roman roads, wear hiking shoes. I've been wanting to visit since I watched "Pink Floyd at Pompeii" years ago, and the amphitheater didn't disappoint. Most of the space under the seats is dedicated to this "concert" in 1971 with no audience, but they seem to know a lot of people visit because of this! It's apparently the biggest thing to hit Pompeii since Vesuvius in 79 AD.

title: Check out this amazing market
text: We took a brief stroll through the meat market, fruit and veggie market, and the seafood market. Other than the fruit and veggies, Americans typically don't get to see this kind of thing. I was there mostly to take pictures, we whisked through quickly so as not to get in their way. Completely recommend.

title: Quite happy!
text: We ate at this restaurant on Monistiraki Square. I had a kebab in pita, quite good, and a Greek salad - usual salad with the enormous block of feta, delicious. My daughter had calamari, per usual. We were both happy. It's not fancy, but gets the job done. Opa!

title: Interesting and convenient hotel near Via Veneto
text: This place is a set of rooms on an upper floor in a relatively ancient building right near the Barberini metro station (currently closed, beware.) No desk, but you'll work out arrangements with the management, and they're very helpful and accessible. Our room was on the 4th floor, reachable by stairs or a tiny ancient elevator (and that's OK, we travel to experience something new/very old!) The rooms are modern and comfortable. We had a little trouble with a leaky shower at first, but enjoyed the place. There's a tiny breakfast area, but oh my, the spread was terrific. Have you had blood orange juice? A first for me, and it's exquisite! They'll make you a cappuccino or espresso. I'd definitely come back.

title: Gelato of the Gods
text: Didn't look this up, just wandered in on the way back from eating at Piazza Navona. I've had gelato this good twice in my life, the other was at a stand in Venice. They've got about 150 kinds, I had chocolate/strawberry, but they've got exotic flavors like champagne, chocolate/pepper and basil.

title: Historic coffee house
text: Had seen that this was recommended for the pastries, coffee, and historic cubist atmosphere/architecture. It was like stepping back into the 1930s for a coffee and pastry, waiters in white jackets. Very much enjoyed.

title: You'll love it.
text: We'd probably covered a few miles in Athens by lunch time and were eager to collapse at a table by the sidewalk in Monastiraki. So happy we did! We kept it simple, split some kebabs and Greek salad, probably the best Greek salad ever served. Prices are good.

title: Sushi in Berlin, whatever!
text: We were at Potsdamerplatz and were hungry. We were also struggling to find a quick place to eat with seating, a lot of things there were grab and go. This place had a few sushi plates with a variety of pieces- rolls and nigiri. Good value, good flavor. My daughter had lived in Japan so we were using a mix of Japanese, German and English. I'm sure the Japanese server thought we were odd. It was fun!

title: If you can't get to Munich, go here
text: We had dinner at the original Hofbrau in Munich a few years ago. We wanted some German food and decided to visit this copy. The food was roughly the same, very good, and the atmosphere at least tried to give the same feel. I had sauerbraten and dumplings (and beer of course) - and waddled out very happy. Has live German music.

title: Comfortable hotel in Alexanderplaz
text: I normally look for hotels that are older and more quaint, but I get the idea those are rare in Berlin, due to the war. This place is hip and modern, has everything to make your stay comfortable. The location is very near great transportation at Alexanderplatz station, which has an attached mall with a variety of restaurants and stores. And the provided breakfast spread is the absolute best I've ever seen, you will not believe your eyes! Would definitely come back.

title: This is the hotel you want!
text: Gorgeous 391 year old hotel, with all needed amenities. Very comfortable, every room a work of art. Nice staff, the full breakfast has a lot of variety and is delicious. Very near Prague Castle and Uvoz St. has beautiful historic buildings lining the street all the way from Charles Bridge. Stay here!

title: Excellent unpretentious Greek food
text: My daughter and I wandered in here without any expectations. We shared a tremendous Greek salad with feta, capers, olive oil and the usual tomatoes, onions, green pepper, kalamata olives. She had the calamari, which she said was the best she's eaten, I had delicious moussaka. Terrific service, recommend.

title: Sura Eats
text: Sura Eats serves Korean food, among several other options, inside the Parlor. I've only had Bibambap a few times before, but this was head and shoulders above any I've had. I tried the beef, and it was perfect - excellent taste and texture with the vegetables and rice.

title: Give it a try!
text: Crispy beef tacos are very good. Pork tamale is excellent. I'll be going back for the barbacoa and al pastor street tacos, however. Really nice staff, too!

title: Good tacos in Japan!
text: We were absolutely starving, and as one occasionally does in Japan, wanted something that wasn't local. Found this place in American Village in Mihama serving Mexican. I had the pastor street tacos and was amazed. Just like home! The tortilla chips and salsa were both odd, I'm not sure they have the recipe down. Even so, I'll go back if I'm ever in Okinawa again.

title: Good food, strange decor
text: Wound up here with friends for lunch when we discovered Pig & Finch wasn't open yet. Had an excellent cheeseburger with bacon on a brioche bun, nice touch. Attentive wait staff. The 1800s New Orleans bordello wallpaper seemed out of place, but whatever.

title: Not bad at all
text: Really enjoyed my BLT there, well done. The garlic fries were very nice. Atmosphere is good and the wait staff were attentive.

title: Take the Bullet Train!
text: Really enjoyed taking a very fast shinkansen (bullet train) from Odawara (near Hakone) to Kyoto. It's not cheap, but a very pleasant mode of transportation. If you're going that direction, sit on the right side and get a view of Mt. Fuji as you fly by at 200mph+.

title: OK Indian Buffet
text: I'm not an expert on Indian food, and this place was popular with some of my Indian co-workers, so I tried it. There's a good variety of dishes available at the buffet, although I've liked the offerings at India Palace and Taj Majal a little better. The mango lassi was outstanding.

title: This train is OK
text: This sushi place is decent. I'm not an expert on great sushi, but after having "sushi-go-round" in Japan I was hankering to try the local version. It's not as fresh or as varied, but really isn't bad. My daughter, who's been eating sushi in Japan for the last couple years, seemed to think it was acceptable.

title: Sushi train surprise
text: Stumbled in with jetlag, was surprised how good sushi/nigiri could be at an inexpensive sushi-go-round place in Tokyo could be. Really liked the raw tuna, my much more sushi-experienced companion seemed pleased as well. Quite a bargain.

title: Made my night
text: If you're in Tokyo and have the chance, wander down by the Gracery Hotel and check out this Godzilla peeking over the side of a building. At night, some suspenseful music plays and he shoots steam and roars while strobe lights go off. I'd always wanted to see Godzilla in person...

title: Economical and excellent
text: Nice inexpensive yakitori izakaya in Kabukicho, Tokyo. A variety of small plate yakitori choices, we tried chicken with scallions, beef, and accidentally got served chicken with cod roe, which was so good we ordered more. We had an excellent little salad with (I could be wrong) daikon radish, what I think were fish flakes, and some seaweed with a tangy sour dressing, and it was outstanding. I would most definitely recommend it, and will definitely return if I'm ever back in Tokyo.

title: Excellent sushi
text: I'd gotten a little more adventurous about eating sushi after visiting Japan, and this place didn't disappoint. I had the chef's assortment, that included some nice fatty tuna nigiri. Probably not as fresh as Tokyo, but still good, I'll go back.

title: Crazy restaurant area
text: Dotonbori is known as a great place to try the local specialties, and it's just a crazy place full of lights and neon and signage, with giant mechanical crabs and whatnot suspended from buildings. Don't miss it.

title: Lovely Cafe in Lush Setting
text: Sesoko is a tiny island accessible from Okinawa by bridge. On our way to the beach we happened across this cafe nestled in the trees. We had iced coffees and a very nice piece of gateau chocolat, surrounded by semi-tropical plants and trees. They even provided some bug repellent since the mosquitos love the place, too.

title: Fun little creatures
text: There are a few types of animal cafes in Tokyo, but we chose the hedgehog cafe because we'd never gotten to handle hedgehogs. They're cute, not exactly cuddly, and you have to wear gloves.

title: Cook at your table
text: My daughter, who's been in Japan a while, recommended we eat at Pepper Lunch by Ueno Park. I'm not sure what else is on the menu, but we both ordered a steak meal. They brought out a sizzling platter with thinly sliced beef around a mound of rice topped with corn, etc. There are additional spices on the table you can add, I did minced garlic. You finish cooking the meat to your liking, and enjoy. Delicious, inexpensive, fun.

title: Gorgeous Buddhist Temple
text: We walked through the Nakamise Market (how could you not?) and shopped on the way to the temple, which is amazing. That giant red lantern! Locals dressed in traditional clothing, and anyone is welcome to light incense and candles and participate, regardless of their beliefs. Do not miss this!

title: Check out this local market
text: Unlike the Nakamise market by the Senso-ji temple, which seems primarily for tourists, this market is for everyone. Restaurants and food stands everywhere, stores selling food and produce, clothing, purses, electronics, pachinko halls. It was crazy busy and should be one of your stops in Tokyo.

title: Overrated, as far as I'm concerned
text: I'd heard that the ramen here was good. We were there at a busy lunchtime and picked out a place and ordered through the machine, which was confusing for a first-timer. The ramen wasn't as good as the kind I make at home in the microwave, as far as I was concerned. Probably just bad luck. We had much better ramen in Japan later...

title: Interesting shopping street and people watching
text: This street has a reputation of catering to teen fashion needs. It's fun to see some of the clothing, both in stores and on the people, and just look at some of the oddness - stores with names like "Listen Flavor," etc. There's also a Daiso 100 yen store that you should visit, and have one of the ice-cream filled crepes.

title: Tranquil
text: We visited on a rainy day. The shrine is in a peaceful wooded area, very beautiful to walk through, saw waterfalls and cranes. As much as it pains me to say, the shrine itself isn't all that, in spite of the historical and cultural significance.

title: Not what you imagine
text: Everyone visiting Tokyo for the first time has to do the Shibuya crossing and see Hachiko, it's a must. That being said, timing must be part of the trick, it wasn't that exciting or interesting when we visited. Kind of like Piccadilly in London, you'll visit and say "hmm."

title: Would fly ANA again
text: Flew a 1:20 AM to Tokyo from LAX. In-seat entertainment was abundant. They served a light snack first. As a nervous flyer I was a little miffed that the drink cart came around only ONCE. After a respectable amount of cabin darkness, they began serving breakfast - I was offered either a Japanese breakfast (mackerel over rice) or a Western breakfast, which oddly included lasagne, Greek yogurt, and cold noodles with miso sauce - it was good but strange. I don't have any trans-Pacific U.S. carrier flights to compare this with.

title: No frills Japanese short haul
text: Peach flies out of a little-used part of Kansai airport, although that makes it less busy. We boarded in a timely manner but sat on the plane for about an hour before we were told to deplane, they put us on buses and made us go through security again. We deplaned in Naha about two hours late at some sort of barely air-conditioned barn of a building, and had to wait for buses to take us to the main part of the airport (another hour gone.) I booked tickets online and had my credit card charged twice due to a problem with their site. Still, tickets were temptingly cheap.

title: Get it together, Southwest!
text: I've flown Southwest dozens of times and never had any problems until now. Arrived in LA after flying out late at night from Tokyo, so I'd already been up 24 hours. Got to my gate not knowing anything was wrong. We started hearing rumors that the flight was delayed. We were told it was a ground hold due to weather, then it was an air traffic control issue, then it was a bird strike that caused the plane to need to be thoroughly checked (which I'm glad they were cautious about.) The flight took off four hours late, arriving at about 4:30 AM.

title: Japanese Waffle House of Ramen
text: We'd had some really awful ramen in, of all places, Ramen Street in Tokyo. This place is terrific, perfect broth, perfect spice, along with some great gyoza.

title: Better than expected
text: The guys at this dive shop really seemed to want to provide a good experience. I'd never snorkeled before, and they made it easy, fit us well with wetsuits and even provided a vision-correcting mask for my daughter. Saw some amazing fish, and our guide even whipped out some cold tea after we finished.

title: Good location for a first time visitor
text: The hotel is huge, the rooms are small, but efficiently designed. They provide an astounding amount of toiletries, yakutas, slippers, etc. I tried the onsen, a new thing for me. It's very near a Family Mart and a lot of restaurants, entertainment, and the train station. It's a good base for a tourist. Do not let anyone tell you Kabukicho is unsafe, it is not. I'd stay here again.

title: Would definitely stay here again
text: This is not a traditional hotel, but kind of a condo right on the ocean. Convenient free parking, nice sized room with a small kitchenette (fridge, stove top) and a washer/dryer. Strong wifi. Nice ocean view. Nice basic continental breakfast in the mornings, nice staff. Very near Araha Beach and Sunset Beach, as well as American Village, Camp Foster, etc. I'd definitely stay here again.

title: Good for both expats and locals
text: I assumed this place would largely cater to American service people and their families, but 80 or 90% of the people I saw were Japanese. it has a good mix of restaurants appealing to just about anyone, in various price ranges. For Americans visiting Okinawa, staying near here is ideal.

title: Really good Indian food in Kyoto
text: For 900 yen at lunch I had a delicious tomato/carrot soup, salad, chana masala curry, unlimited naan, and a soda, served with a smile, while I watched Indian pop music on TV. This is perfect.

title: Top site in Kyoto
text: Gorgeous dramatic Tori gates and shrine buildings, beautiful regardless of what time of day you visit. Cute fox messenger statues. Don't miss this.

title: Western style breakfast in Yokohama
text: My daughter and her friend were interested in having an American-style breakfast, hard to come by in mainland Japan. This chain out of Hawaii did the trick. I had a nice simple omelette, fried potatoes and pancakes. Pancakes with guava and coconut syrup, which made them a special experience.

title: Freaky enough to be worth it
text: Tickets for this aren't cheap, and it's mostly for western tourists, but it was a good time. I've never seen anything like this before, and probably never will again. Lasers, robots, taiko drums, neon, fireworks, incredible video display. Tacky and crazy. You won't be sorry.

title: High up view of this incredible city
text: This is a free attraction. We waited in a short line and went to the north observation deck, where you can see the whole city. A good choice if you're in a hurry and don't want to pay for the Sky Tree.
place: Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observation Decks

title: Do not be afraid
text: This area of town has an unfortunate reputation of being dangerous - maybe by Japanese standards, but not by anyone else's. Crazy lights, people, nightlife.

title: Gorgeous Temple
text: If you visit Japan, make time for visiting Nara Park, home of the sweet little tame deer, and this priceless temple. The hall of the two large Buddhas was a dramatic and moving as visiting Notre Dame in Paris or St. Peter's Basilica.

title: Yeah, we ate at Krispy Kreme in Tokyo, twice
text: Very few places in Tokyo open before 10 AM. This place caters to western tastes, with a twist, I had an excellent mango cream donut, and they had some more exotic flavors, like green tea and German Potato (no, not good, it's a sweet donut filled with German mashed potatoes.)
place: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts SHINJUKU TOHO BLDG

title: You've never seen anything like this
text: We went on a horrible rainy morning and had a good time anyway. A crazy variety of the freshest seafood available anywhere. I saw a live snow crab with a body the size of a small turkey and a lot of other fish and shellfish I didn't recognize. If you're in the mood, apparently you can get some of the best sushi in the world here, and I don't doubt it.

title: Quiet little ryokan
text: This was our first time in a ryokan, really enjoyed the experience of wearing the yakuta and slippers, padding down the hallway with the rice paper walls. The private onsen was enjoyable once we figured out how to get the water below 200 degrees F. They have a vending machine with beer and hi-chu, and free ice cream bars in the pantry area. I'd recommend this to anyone wanting a little bit of an experience instead of another tiny modern Japanese hotel room.

title: Fun little switchback railway
text: The trip up to Gora takes about 45 minutes and winds you through some magnificent scenery, which is why you go to Hakone.

title: Cute little alley of tiny yakitori bars
text: We really enjoyed the experience of walking up and down looking at the tiny yakitori bars and finally settled on one. The yakitori and gyoza were outstanding.

title: Really terrific Japanese curry
text: My daughter, who eats at this chain on the mainland, recommended the chicken cutlets, 300 grams of rice, and a spice level of two, which was hot by my standards but mild by theirs. Delicious! They even had manga for patrons to read, if you can read Japanese...

title: Amazing empanadas
text: I had the shredded chicken and a shredded beef empanada, both with cheese. They were prepared quickly and were quite delicious.

title: Go for the street tacos
text: I had the street tacos, chicken, asada and barbacoa. Very tasty, excellent homemade tortillas. Am anxious to go back and try the pasole.

title: Skip Sea World, Visit the Sea
text: At the right time of day, the tide pools here are incredible. The tide goes out, and reveals all these little worlds of unbelievably colorful sea urchins and anemone. Plus there's this gorgeous green seaweed (or slime?) covering everything. Check out the seal beach, too.

title: Trendy BBQ
text: Q39 is good, don't get me wrong, it's just not quite up to the gold standard set by Kansas City Joe's. My brisket sandwich was smoked perfectly, the sauce was a little thin and lacking. Baked beans good but not great. Fries are pretty run of the mill, and quite expensive compared to the volume of the much better fries at Joe's. Again, this place isn't bad, the wait staff was great, it's just second best.

title: Flower garden is small
text: Frankly, even though the price of admission is fairly low, the flower garden is on the small side and probably not worth it. Lots of trails for hiking, I'd just go elsewhere to satisfy your botanical interests.
place: Overland Park Arboretum and Botanical Gardens

title: Loved the bento Box
text: I tried a Bento box with bulgogi ribeye - served with rice, miso soup, salad, and some kind of pickled vegetables, while my daughter had the chicken-based shoyu ramen. I thought it was terrific.

title: Delicious Indian buffet
text: The biryani, chicken tikka masala, chana masala, palak paneer and naan bread, among other things, is excellent. They've got a variety of Indian dishes to try. Will be back again and again.

title: Nice Boutique Hotel
text: Located very near the Grand Street subway stop, and convenient to a lot of walkable attractions and restaurants. My room had a little mini-bar fridge, and an Alexa I could ask questions of, as well as (maybe?) a 4K flatscreen. It was clean, quiet, comfortable and kind of hip, the elevators are covered in vintage album covers, for example. The staff was helpful in giving directions.

title: Great burgers
text: I had a cheeseburger, the crinkle-cut fries and a chocolate malt, which were all out of this world. My city doesn't have a Shake Shack yet but I can't wait.
